Definitions

the object of the present invention is a system and method to control access of people to facilities, such as banking institutions, companies, industrial estates, etc., where only authorized people are allowed access.

Inventions that already exist use a combination of biometric readings, unique passwords, cards with magnetic stripes, passwords typed in using a keyboard and the use of physical keys to allow people to access protected perimeters where these systems are applied.

the document US8823497B2 uses a system made up of a card with registered data and uses the readings of biometric parameters as a password.

the document US7283054B2 shows a bracelet that has an integrated RFID circuit, which has registered information that allows it to function as a key when this information is correct.

the document US8207816B2 is also known, which shows an access control system for a weapons storage system, which implements readings of biometric inputs and uses RFID antennas.

the present invention reinforces current security systems and methods through a system and method to control the access of people to facilities, which detect if a person is under pressure or in a situation of coercion, in which case it prevents the entry of such people to the facilities.

the system for controlling access to a facility comprises: a reading device, intended to be installed in a door that provides access to the facility, and which comprises a set of retractable latches which extend or retract to or from a door frame as a function of the access data, and an emitting device intended to be worn by a person and which comprises said access data.

the emitting device comprises a chip for reading and recording the access data and a heart rate reader intended to measure the heart rate of the person.

this chip records the person's heartbeats and a unique code assigned to said emitting device and/or to said person.

Both the chip and the heart rate reader are electrically powered by a rechargeable battery, which is also comprised in the emitting device.

the emitting device is a bracelet or accessory for the wrist.

the reading device comprises a reading/recording element intended to read the unique code and the heart rate, a screen intended to show personal information of the person, a biometric reader intended to record a fingerprint of the person, a horn and at least one light to indicate whether or not the person is granted access to the facility, an electrical connector to make the connection to the electrical grid, an emergency electric battery in case of power failure, and a wireless network connector to have access to the access control system database, which is located in a physical server of the system. Preferably, this database is located in the IT security system of the building itself.

the reading device also comprises a microcontroller, which is linked to all of the components comprised in the reading device, to assess whether or not access should be granted to the person.

the microcontroller executes the method for access control which comprises the following stages: reading the recorded heart rate and unique code comprised in the chip through the reading/recording element, registering this heart rate and the unique code in the database connected to the network of the server of the access control system, verifying the unique code with that of the database and assigning a new code in the chip and in the database, comparing the heart rate to the range of values that comprises at least one previously registered heart rate in the database for the person; when the heart rate is not within said range, maintaining the latches extracted and blocking access to facilities and showing a feedback by means of colors and sounds emitted by the light and by the horn, respectively; when the heart rate is within said range, requesting that the person place their preferred finger in the biometric reader in order for their fingerprint to be read, verifying the fingerprint in the database, and when the fingerprint is located

a system administrator enters the data of each person who has access to the facility into a database and previously provides a first unique code and/or a first heart rate to each emitting device.

the access control system will be waiting for an access request, and once the user has the emitting device and proceeds to request access to the area, the reading device will proceed to take the readings of the emitting device of the user.

the system will compare the records saved in the database connected to the access control system network and, depending on the results, will either grant or deny access to the area.

the microprocessor will block the person's access for a period of 24 hours as a security measure against possible threats where the person might be involved in a high-risk situation causing their vital signs to be altered.

One advantage of the invention is that unique code varies with each reading, unlike other inventions that use permanent codes that may easily be copied.

This invention is more secure than others since it combines random unique codes with specific heart rate ranges and fingerprints of the person. This combination makes it impossible for third parties to use force against people who have access to facilities to make them open the door.

Another advantage of the invention is the use of an emergency electric battery in the case of a power failure within the facility, generating records of the failure and of all people who entered before, during and after the power outage, thereby preventing possible intruders.

Another advantage of the invention is the rechargeable battery of the emitting device, which makes it more environmentally friendly since it reduces the amount of disposable batteries that are purchased.

a preferred embodiment of the present invention is an access control system that comprises a reading device (1) by way of a lock on a door, wherein this reading device (1) establishes communication with an emitting device (9), intended to be worn by a person.

figures 1 and 2 show an emitting device (9) which comprises a chip (10) for reading and recording the access data linked to a heart rate reader (1 1) intended to measure and record the heart rate of the person wearing the emitting device (9).

a heart rate reader (1 1) intended to measure and record the heart rate of the person wearing the emitting device (9).

Both the chip (10) and the heart rate reader (1 1) are electrically powered by a rechargeable battery (12), which is also comprised in the emitting device (9).

this chip In addition to recording the person's heartbeats, or the recorded heart rate (16), this chip (10) records a unique code (17).

this emitting device (9) is an accessory for the wrist.

figures 3 to 8 show different views of the reading device (1) and of the access control method, wherein the reading device (1) is intended to be placed in the lock of the door of the facility to control the access of people.

This reading device (1) comprises a reading/recording element (3) intended to read the unique code (17) and the recorded heart rate (16), a screen (2) intended to show information, and a biometric reader (4) intended to record a fingerprint (14).

At least the reading/recording element (3), the screen (2) and the biometric reader (4) are controlled by a microcontroller, not shown, which, once the unique code (17) is read, emits a new unique code (15) and classifies the recorded heart rate (16). If this recorded heart rate (16) is within the normal range, that is to say between 60 and 80 beats per minute, it is considered to be within a normal range and therefore information is then requested (name, surname, a recent photo, the department in which the person works, etc.) of the person who is wearing the emitting device (9) from a database (13) and this information is shown on the screen (2). Once the information is shown on the screen, the microcontroller proceeds with the biometric reading of the fingerprint (14) by means of the biometric reader (4).

the reading device (1) will show a feedback of the person wearing the emitting device (9) with colors and sounds, which will be made by lights (5) and horns (8), respectively.

figure 2 shows a front schematic view of the reading device (1) located in the lock of the door, wherein the reading device (1) comprises a set of retractable latches (6) that extend or retract depending on whether or not access is granted to the person wearing the emitting device (9). More specifically, figure 7 shows how the latches (6) of the reading device (1) are intended to be coupled, when they are extended, at stations (7) made in the doorframe.

Figure 8 shows the flow chart of the access control method that is preferably done by the microcontroller. More specifically, this method comprises the steps of: reading the recorded rate (16) and the unique code (17) comprised in the chip (10) by means of the reading/recording element (3), recording this recorded heart rate (16) and the unique code (17) in the database, verifying the unique code (17) with that of the database and assigning a new unique code (15), comparing the recorded heart rate (16) to a range of values considered to be normal for the person wearing the emitting device (9); when the recorded heart rate (16) is within said range, requesting and taking a reading of the fingerprint (14) by means of a biometric reader (4), verifying the fingerprint (14) in the database, and when this fingerprint is located in the database, proceeding to retract the latches (6) and grant access to the area.
